summary: All Quiet on the Western Front tells the gripping story of a young German soldier on the Western Front of World War I. Paul and his comrades experience first-hand how the initial euphoria of war turns into desperation and fear as they fight for their lives, and each other, in the trenches. The film from director Edward Berger is based on the world renowned bestseller of the same name by Erich Maria Remarque.

All Quiet on the Western Front 2022 is a German-language adaptation of Erich Maria Remarque's classic anti-war novel, which follows the experiences of a young soldier named Paul Bäumer on the Western Front during World War I. Directed by Edward Berger, the film stars Felix Kammerer as Paul, Albrecht Schuch as his mentor Kat, and Daniel Brühl as a school official who encourages Paul and his friends to enlist.

The film is faithful to the source material, capturing the horror, futility, and tragedy of war through Paul's eyes. The cinematography by James Friend is stunning, creating a contrast between the bleak and muddy trenches and the idyllic countryside that Paul longs for. The film also adds a parallel storyline that shows the armistice negotiations to end the war, which provides some historical context and a sense of irony.

The acting is superb, especially by Kammerer and Schuch, who convey the bond between Paul and Kat as they face death and despair together. Brühl is also effective as the patriotic teacher who later regrets his influence on his students. The film does not shy away from showing the brutality and violence of war, as well as its psychological impact on the soldiers. The film also explores themes such as friendship, loyalty, innocence, and humanity in the midst of chaos.

The film is not without flaws, however. The film is long, running at 147 minutes, and some scenes feel repetitive or unnecessary. The film also suffers from some pacing issues, especially in the second half, where it loses some of its momentum and emotional impact. The film could have benefited from some editing and trimming to make it more concise and focused.

Overall, All Quiet on the Western Front 2022 is a powerful and poignant film that honors its source material and delivers a strong anti-war message. It is one of the best war films of recent years, and deserves to be seen by a wide audience. The film has received critical acclaim and several awards nominations, including Best Picture at the Academy Awards. I would rate it 4 out of 5 stars.

Films based on real life wars, while excelling with the film-making aspects, also exude sadness, despair and sometimes even trauma. In that sense, this one isn't any different and has to be watched keeping all those factors in mind.
"All Quiet on the Western Front", a German film, finds itself in a league of recent war-based predecessors like "1917", "Dunkirk" and classics like "Saving Private Ryan", "The Thin Red Line", "Full Metal Jacket", "Platoon" and even "Apocalypse Now". I would be damned if I didn't mention Spielberg's classic series "Band of Brothers" in that list.
In fact, the story based on the 1929 novel by Erich Maria Remarque with the same name has been brought to the silver screen before – once as an Oscar winning feature film in 1930 and then as a TV film in 1979. While most of the main characters remain constant, there are subtle variations in the on-screen depictions, albeit retaining the painful ironies of war in the story.
One could say this is a perspective from the opposite side of the trenches to that of the saga depicted in the acclaimed film "1917" (2019), another World War I story. "All Quiet on the Western Front" follows a German youth's journey into the throes of war, with the zest of patriotism and an almost delusional enthusiasm, that blinds out the deadly consequences of a conflict.
He soon descends into the dark chasm of war as they get closer to the battlefront and combat in the trenches, and it isn't too far in days, months or even years for him to transition into a futile, brainwashed soldier conflicted with his humane instincts.
As one would expect, the locations and set production is intricate taking you right into the blend of gorgeous fields, forests and the corpse stricken battlefield, engulfed in mist and smoke. The set design and cinematography deservedly took home top accolades at the 95th Academy awards, besides being recognized as the best International feature film and a haunting score that enlivens the doom of war, by Volker Bertelmann. And Edward Berger's direction is laudable.
The young Felix Kammerer immerses himself into a journey that takes him from a naïve youth to being a bayonet stabbing soldier, Paul and Albrecht Schuch as the other key protagonist and a sort of mentor is as intense. Daniel Brühl is easily recognizable for the global audience in that role of a struggling German diplomat, and so is Sebastian Hülk from "Dark", that iconic drama that was built around temporal loops and parallel universes before that theme really went into overkill in recent films.
A gem that came through and was produced by Netflix, it is best watched in the original German audio with subtitles. A brush through about the first war in the 20th century would definitely throw some light on the background of the events in the film.
Wars and national conflicts have always risen from the depths of political agendas, driven by ego and the hunger to expand an elusive border or even stamp a barbaric foot of authority between countries. This story re-emphasizes the fact that war has been, and will always remain a futile act of genocide.

"All Quiet on the Western Front" is based on the 1929 novel by Erich Maria Remarque, who was a German foot soldier on the western front during World War I.  (The "front" stretched from the west coast of Belgium through Germany's western border with France down to the border of neutral Switzerland.)  The book was the best-selling novel in the US in its year of publication and sold 1.5 million copies worldwide in its first eighteen months.  In 1930, an American adaptation of the book won Best Picture at the third Academy Awards.
Like the novel, this film traces the story of Paul Bäumer and his friends, who join the German war effort in 1917 in a fit of patriotic fervor.  Almost immediately, the realities of life – and death – on the front expose the naïveté of the characters' initial expectations.    
The major theme of this film is the futility of war.  As the film concludes, story cards inform us that between 1913 and 1917, there were over two million casualties along the western front, even though the territorial lines moved less than 200 meters.  In fact, "all quiet on the western front" is now a euphemism for stagnation.
Cowriter/Director Edward Berger departs from the narrative of the novel by inserting a storyline about Matthias Erzberger, the German diplomat who negotiated (or acquiesced to) an armistice with the French.  While these scenes offer stark contrast to the war footage (at one point, the French general worries that the croissants are not truly fresh), this subplot is a misguided distraction.
Berger's creative team is excellent.  Cinematographer James Friend and Composer Volker Bertelmann deserve special mention.  Friend's graphic set pieces on the battlefield and his lingering shots of untouched natural scenery create an effectively eerie juxtaposition.  His washed-out color palette ironically makes the horrors on the screen even more vivid.  For his part, Bertelmann employs snare drums and a three-note motif using a harmonium to jolt the moviegoer and create a pervasive, bone-deep sense of dread.
This film effectively communicates the realities of the western front and, more generally, WW I from a German perspective.  Since "history is written by the victors," the suffering on the German side has often gone unacknowledged.  Early on, there are poignant scenes of German soldiers removing boots and clothing from the dead.  The apparel is then transported back to German factories where it is washed, repaired and presented to recruits as "new" uniforms.  
The flaw here is that "All Quiet" is basically a series of memorable images.  Unlike Sam Mendes' film "1917," there's no powerful narrative to fully immerse us in the events that are unfolding.  The only dramatic tension is whether the war will end before all the key characters die.  One horror simply piles onto the next, frame after frame, day after day.  And while some of these scenes are quite striking, (the imagery of advancing allied battle tanks and soldiers with flamethrowers looks truly terrifying from the other side), we come away shell-shocked but emotionally disengaged.

"All Quiet on The Western Front" is a film that left me conflicted. Initially, it came across as a stark and emotionless portrayal of war that left no one spotless. Unlike other historical war films, it doesn't depict the soldiers as valiant or patriotic. Instead, it shows the futility of war, the loss of youth, and the corruption of innocence with an unsettling lack of emotion throughout. The characters are naive and impressionable young men who have mindlessly partaken in the unwarranted military occupation of foreign land, where they are obviously not welcome by the inhabitants. They are not fighting for glory or honor, but for their survival.

While this inability to sympathize with the characters is irksome, it is intentional, as the film tells the story from the perspective of the vanquished, not the conquerors. The recruits were fatally misled in conscripting themselves and their families, and once they arrived at the front, they were gradually numbed to their feelings by the constant mental and physical anguish inflicted upon them. However, this noticeable detachment from the characters featured results in a somewhat muted response when they are chewed up and spat out by the gratuitous violence they are repeatedly thrust into by the callous, cowardly officers. Despite this, the film does accurately reflect how Germany treated its own people, offering up generations of its future citizens on the battlefield as sacrificial lambs, massacred at the altar of a poisonous, nationalistic ideology. Boys were essentially reduced to nothing but disposable, unimportant objects, thoughtlessly discarded and simply replaced in a sadistic game and quest for absolute power. The movie lenses the apathy of the superiors through a perspective of rightful, scornful contempt.

Overall, the film achieves its goal in a commendably brutal and unflinching manner. It shows the utter, irredeemable meaninglessness and the wanton, senseless destruction of war. While it may leave the viewer with a cynical, bitter, and despondent conclusion, it is an understandably accurate portrayal of the carnage we observe. It also shows one massive miscalculation on the side of the victors, forcing the Germans into reluctant submission and backing them into signing an agreement with terms they couldn't accept, ultimately entrenching resentful animosity that would act as a spark to light the fire of the Second World War.

Im Westen Nichts Neues, the latest film adaptation of Erich Maria Remarque's classic novel, is a disappointing and absurd attempt at depicting the horrors of war. The blame, however, does not solely lie with the poor directorial choices and budget allocation, but also with Netflix's commercialization of the movie.

The film's story has been altered in ways that serve no purpose and only serve to alienate the original book. The pseudo-historical events depicted in the movie, such as the peace-agreement between Germany and France, are a disgrace to the depth and nuance of Remarque's work. These changes make no sense and leave viewers questioning the plot and its execution.

The 1930 adaptation of the novel was a masterpiece, with superior artistic vision and direction, which makes this recent adaptation all the more frustrating. The poor allocation of budget and mismanagement by the director are evident in the lack of proper representation of war. The scenes that are meant to depict war come off as cheap and superficial, lacking any real substance or depth.

The actors' performances are commendable, but they are let down by the absurdity of the script. The peace-agreement and negotiations between Germany and France, though they did take place historically, had no place or mention in the book. This artificial introduction of pseudo-historical events in the movie is dishonoring the book's depth and nuance.

In conclusion, Im Westen Nichts Neues is a brutal and absurd attempt at depicting the horrors of war. While the actors' performances are commendable, the poor directorial choices and the mismanagement of the budget leave the movie lacking in substance and depth. The changes to the plot are unwarranted and only serve to alienate the original book. This movie is a disservice to Remarque's classic novel and the 1930 adaptation of the same.

The film begins with an exuberant yet shallow speech that was supposed to be patriotic. The resulting euphoric camaraderie was quickly smothered by one soldier's callous remark guaranteeing the demise of his other fellow soldier. The film continues with similar snide and aloof dialogue paired with intricately-horrifying-battle-scene after intricately-horrifying-battle-scene. In contrast, the audience is offered brief glimpses into impressively-mustached commanders' hearty dinner tables, where they're eating chicken, completely oblivious to the mortal devastation going on just outside their window. Then again: more fighting, death, mud, and people staring off into space.

The nihilistic principles that this film took 2 hours and 45 minutes to portray are as follows:
War sucks.
People suck.
And what's even the f***ing point?

When making a statement on the woes of war, if you want to offer meaning behind the horrific realities, it's important to tell the whole story rather than just part of it. In this case, the film neglected to represent other key-concepts of war: camaraderie, honor, belief — Without the contrast of these core principles, the shell-shock the actors so-beautifully portrayed was distant and un-relatable, and the intricate battles were aimless and cold.

Apparently, our only hope is to grow an impressive mustache and hope for the best.

It's easy to dismiss the conclusion that war is hell. It seems like a statement of the abundantly obvious, one which may have lost power in repetition. This war film - is it an adaptation, a remake or a completely fresh take? - manages to restate that old truth, and finds reasons for the message's fresh urgency. 

These are not only the ongoing war in Ukraine, but in a skilful way, the film weaves throughout its length a depiction of the vicious circle of toxic nationalism and industrialised militarism. One can't survive without the other, and how they constantly feed on each other is especially chilling in the light of events we're watching play out on the news not only from Ukraine but from wherever the spirit of nationalism energies the military-industrial complex. 

It's a remarkably made film on almost every level - writing, acting, and every technical aspect. The score haunts and chills with percussive beats, and insistent drones; colours in and around the battlefield are almost perpetually washed out and presented with a metallic, industrial patina. On more than one occasion a trick of make-up or cinematography leads to a sense that the dead appear to be alive, the living seems dead. Back in headquarters, the colours are as bright as they are drained at the front; the food as rich as it is scarce for the soldiers. The tank attack on German trenches is especially hard to watch - the sequence of tanks rolling across and into an open trench of soldiers is as frightening as anything I've seen in a long time; not just for the violence it depicts, but also for the horrified faces of those who look down the trench at their companions being crushed and see everything that's coming to them. 

The climactic German decision to walk into battle fifteen minutes before the Armistice comes into effect seems both as stupid as it was and entirely in keeping with what has come before; the ultimate hard-sell of nationalism's false gospel, the relentless need to feed the military machine as it gorges on young lives and a ruined natural world. The land that is meant to feed and nurture life is the killing floor of a personalised, mechanised descent into a hell that pays well for those a thousand miles away.

Like many films which tell such resonant stories, it remains hard to objectively judge All Quiet On The Western Front. It's most certainly a film that has found its time, and deserves the wide audience it is exposed to on Netflix; though one can't also help thinking this would be all the more overwhelmingly intense on a big screen. Upsetting, intimate, visceral and horrifying, it remains an all too human tragedy that there is no film this year more urgent than this.

"All Quiet on the Western Front" opens on an obliterated battlefield somewhere in the European countryside with smooth camerawork that throws audiences into the macabre and destructive reality of World War 1. The chilling scene follows a young German soldier as he is forced over the top of the trenches into no man's land, and to his premature death. Director Edward Berger's adaptation marks the third time Erich Maria Remarque's book, which was inspired by his own experiences as a German soldier during World War 1, has been adapted for the big screen, with directors Lewis Milestone and Delbert Mann each bringing their own version of the novel to life.

Like the novel of the same name, "All Quiet on the Western Front" tells the story of a young Paul Bäumer (Felix Kammerer) as he and his friends, blinded by heroic aspirations and childish naivety, sign up to fight in World War 1. Heads filled with dreams to serve the fatherland and return as heroes, the boys soon arrive on the frontline, but what they see immediately upends every expectation they had about the war, as the dreams quickly fade into a vicious fight for survival. Determined to make it out of the waterlogged trenches and away from the ravaged battlefields of the European countryside, Paul and his friends fight tooth and nail in order to survive. While on the other side of it all, safe and dry in the comfort of luxurious train carriages, German diplomats negotiate with the French in order to stop the war once and for all. But as Paul sees his friends slowly picked off one by one, the chaos and devastation of the war soon begin to hit home for Paul, as he is forced to come to terms with the harsh reality of conflict. 
While this adaptation, written by Berger alongside Lesley Paterson and Ian Stockell, does for the most part follow the narrative of Remarque's novel, he leaves out multiple parts, and changes bits and pieces throughout. Berger also decides to change the ending from the one in the book, and luckily for Berger it works in his favour, making the final scene in the film an emotional gut-punch just like the ending in the novel. Remarque's novel also doesn't include any sort of political negotiations as seen in the film, but these scenes do allow for a stark contrast between the violence and mess of battle, and the decadence and luxury of politics, making way for a strong performance by Daniel Brühl. Berger also shifts focus in the film away from Paul, unlike Remarque's novel which focuses almost entirely on Paul and his first-hand experience of the war. Despite deviating from the source material, "All Quiet of the Western Front" still manages to be a stellar adaptation of an incredibly well written novel from nearly 100 years ago. The film is led by a stellar (and BAFTA-nominated) directorial effort from Berger as he miraculously crafts a compelling film from a dark, deeply disturbing story.
Volker Bertelmann provides "All Quiet on the Western Front" with a score that is both menacing, poignant, and with a booming tone paired with the delicate sounds of a violin and a sprinkle of drums. Bertelmann's work feels like strong competition for Justin Hurwitz's luscious score for Damien Chazelle's 1920s Hollywood epic "Babylon" in the 2023 Oscar's race. While the film may be a technical marvel, it also features some sensational performances from it's entire ensemble. Felix Kammerer makes his acting debut with the film, delivering a powerful performance that effortlessly balances the mindset of a soldier deep in the trenches with inexperience, and the innocence of a boy thrown into the deep of the conflict. Kammerer's performance highlights the trauma and terror these soldiers were forced to experience, while also acting as a lifeline for viewers in the midst of the conflict. Albert Schuch brings the character of Stanislaus Katcinzinsky, a soldier alongside the four friends, to the screen. The German actor delivers a remarkable performance that tells a completely different story to the frightened performances given by Felix Kammerer, Aaron Hilmer, Mortiz Klaus, and Adrien Grünewald.

"All Quiet on the Western Front" is a film powered by its impressive technicality with the complex performances given by the cast, and a star-making debut from Felix Kammerer. Edward Berger crafts an immensely emotional, and impactful piece of cinema that feels worthy of all of the accolades it has received. Erich Maria Remarque's novel is a perfect film to be adapted for the big screen, and even with the new additions and subtractions from Berger, Paterson, and Stokell, it makes for an incredibly entertaining war flick. This is a film that takes its audiences on a journey through grief, conflict, chaos and the horrors of World War 1. "All Quiet on the Western Front" is an incredibly powerful film, led by an equally powerful performance from Felix Kammerer, director Edward Berger crafts a devastatingly beautiful film from Erich Maria Remarque's absorbing novel.

A few years ago, I was on a quest to watch every Best Picture Oscar winner that I hadn't seen yet, and that endeavour proved to be a mixed bag. One of the numerous highlights was watching Lewis Milestone's anti-war epic All Quiet On The Western Front. Brutal, visceral and with themes that will never not be relevant and powerful, it was an incredibly rewarding watch. 2022's adaptation of the classic novel got a lot of buzz around awards season, and it had some big shoes to fill. Luckily, Edward Berger had the confidence and the ability to make an adaptation that's both difficult to watch and impossible to look away from. It's got gorgeous cinematography, which often clashes right up against the film's haunting visuals and deliberate ugliness. The performances are incredible, especially Felix Kammerer in the lead role, playing a character who slowly and irreversibly loses his sanity through years of attrition and suffering. The shots on his face demonstrate both his physical and mental deterioration, and it's a truly heart-breaking performance that will likely define his career for year to come. I don't understand the backlash the film's received, with people saying it doesn't capture the spirit of the novel, which dealt with the dehumanisation of soldiers through constant battles and endless bloodshed, as well as criticising the selfish and power-hungry army generals who are content to feed thousand of young fellow countrymen to the wolves it if means gaining a few inches of ground. The film does all of this and does it well. Something this film disappointingly lacks is any coverage of the soldiers when they get back home and are hailed as heroes, but never feel like it. It's some of the most power material the 1930 film had, but this new version is more focused on the war itself, rather than its aftermath. That's not necessarily a bad thing, since it covers the fighting so well, but it's an integral part of the whole picture that I think should have been included. With that being said, this was a truly gripping viewing experience, directed brilliantly, acted perfectly, visually stunning and emotionally resonant. It does things better than the 1930 version and it does things worse, but when judged solely on its own merits, I think its one of the best films released in 2022, and one of the best war films I've seen for a very long time.

War movies aren't normally my thing, so the only time I watch them is when they're Oscar-nominated and it's a genre they love honoring again and again, from the recent Dunkirk and 1917 right back to the first film based on Erich Remarque's novel, which actually won Best Picture in 1930. Now, we have Edward Berger's new adaptation, a technically impressive film that spares us no details in its graphic and uncompromising portrayal of the brutality and inhumanity of war, even when his camera finds occasional beauty amongst the horrors, but is always conscious of its central, timeless and oh-so-familiar message regarding the futility (and randomness) of war. Beginning with someone whom viewers might think is one of the main characters charging haplessly into battle, only to find that this is only a prologue foreshadowing the fate of a quartet of young and ill-prepared German recruits whose initial naive enthusiasm will quickly turn far too real and calamitous once they reach the front line, the film elegantly sets the stage for their harrowing experience in the trenches of WWI whilst intercutting with Daniel Bruhl (whose presence seems mandatory in any Germanic film) as the diplomat representing the new German government desperately negotiating a ceasefire with the French. More advanced technology the filmmakers now have at their disposal aside, the other justification for this remake is that this is the first German and German-made adaptation which inevitably carries extra weight and poignancy. Beautifully and convincingly played by a cast of fresh young faces, especially Felix Kammerer who's the viewers' surrogate, and a screenplay that has time to juxtapose the sickening disparity between the starving soldiers and the luxury their commanding officers wallow in, Berger's film deserves all the nominations it has amassed, but it's too traumatic for a re-watch anytime soon.

Adapted from Erich Maria Remarque's 1929 novel of the same name, All Quiet on the Western Front is an astonishing anti-war film that establishes the events of World War One from a German's perspective. The story follows German student Paul Bäumer, who goes to war with his friends in hopes of gaining glory and honour when they return home from the Front. After months of propaganda and patriotic speeches, the boys begin the journey to Northern France. The true horrors of trench warfare, however, shatter their romanticised view of the war and leave them traumatised. After an infantry offensive and a major gas attack on their first day, the boys are horrified by what lies ahead.

The film itself was produced in Germany and the cast is not as recognisable as other war films I had previously watched such as Dunkirk and 1917, especially with those featuring some of my favourite actors such as Andrew Scott and Benedict Cumberbatch, who have become household names for people in the UK. All Quiet on the Western Front, however, blew these two films out of the water. The casting was phenomenal, especially Felix Kammerer, who played the protagonist. His emotional range throughout this film is an absolute whirlwind and is guaranteed to keep you hooked throughout the whole movie.

One of my favourite scenes is when Kammerer's character Paul takes down a French soldier while retreating to the German trenches. Paul is seen watching him bleed out, but soon regrets what he has done and cannot bare to watch someone die because of him. He becomes hysterical and desperately tries to stop his bleeding to no avail. Upon his death, Paul finds a picture of a woman and a little girl in his pocket, who he soon realises to be the man's wife and child. He becomes inconsolable and lies beside the solider as he sobs with regret, realising that he has torn apart a family. This scene is incredibly powerful and highlights the fragility of life on the battlefield as well as the regrets that many faced by the men of the war. Kammerer's performance truly adds a heart-breaking feel to this scene that wouldn't be the same without him.

It's also interesting to see Paul's overall character development throughout the film. As someone who never read the original novel, I didn't know what to expect when this film was originally suggested to me. Paul starts as an enthusiastic and honest young teen, who is ready to do anything for his country, but he is left broken by war and completely unrecognisable by the end. This also adds to the tear-jerking ending of this film, which I will not spoil.

However, one major part of this film is its shock-factor. The gore and the grittiness of this film is something that cannot be ignored and was truly unexpected in my opinion. In films like Dunkirk and 1917, the gore is not a notable part of their narratives, it mainly focuses on their storyline. However, All Quiet on the Western Front plays mostly off its gore, with some truly horrifying images with are honestly haunting. For example, there is a particular scene that spring to mind where the Germans are under attack from allied forces, who are using tanks. The allies not only unload major artillery on the Germans but also run straight over their trenches. As disgusting as it sounds, you physically see the mangling of people under the tires of tanks, and it is truly horrifying to watch. So much so that when I suggested my friend watch this film, she called me in utter shock at what she had just seen. I would truly say this film is not for people with weak stomachs, but it only adds to the truth of this horrifying war. I do promise that this film is not all gory, some light-hearted scenes fill you with hope, such as the boys robbing a farm or their flirting with passing French female civilians. This film truly encompasses all elements of war.

Overall, this movie is an absolute masterpiece and is undoubtedly one of the grittiest, yet most accurate war films I have ever seen. I adored this film and honestly see no way it could have improved.

All Quiet on the Western Front is a dark, gritty, and depressing look at what the effects of war and propaganda have on the soldiers who enlist.

Our main characters enter the front all bright eyed and bushy tailed excited to fight for Germany, mainly due to them being naive about what war is truly like. That optimism is soon destroyed in the first minutes of reaching the battlefields as they are hit with mortar strikes that kill countless numbers of their comrades. This is where we first get to see the incredible emotion portrayed in this film. The actors do so much with just their facial expressions to demonstrate their mental decay as the turmoil of war inflict their damage.

There is a constant theme of the destruction of peace throughout the entire film, whether be the peace of Germany as a whole due to the lackluster treaty they are forced to sign or the disturbance within the troop themselves. Every time our main characters have a sense of calm, like having a pleasant chat while on guard duty or stealing chickens from a local farmer, that calm is interrupted by more death and destruction. These lulls in action provide a sense of comfortability for the audience that gets ripped away in a second's notice. This juxtaposition occurs throughout the entire film, and I found in incredibly effective.

The tension of war is aided with a brilliant score. The subtle piano keys mixed with loud bass crashes create an uneasiness that spells impending doom for our main troop. It was quite excellent.

As previously stated, the performances here are downright incredible. Felix Kammerer was brilliant in his leading role. His evolution from an absolute wreck of soldier, crying and panicking on the battlefield to grizzled vet who is able to run headfirst into battle without a second notice was fantastic. But he still kept the sweet and genuine attitude throughout, having moments of clarity during the battle where he realizes the brutality of what he and his other soldiers are doing. These complex emotions are carried over to the majority of the cast and was one of my favorite parts about this film.

Overall, All Quiet on the Western Front was a major surprise for me. I am not super experienced nor am interested in many war films, but this may have changed my tune because I genuinely believe it is one of the best movies of the year.

Adapted from Erich Maria Remarque's 1929 novel of the same name, All Quiet on the Western Front is an astonishing anti-war film that establishes the events of World War One from a German's perspective. The story follows German student Paul Bäumer, who goes to war with his friends in hopes of gaining glory and honour when they return home from the Front. After months of propaganda and patriotic speeches, the boys begin the journey to Northern France. The true horrors of trench warfare, however, shatter their romanticised view of the war and leave them traumatised. After an infantry offensive and a major gas attack on their first day, the boys are horrified by what lies ahead. 

The film itself was produced in Germany and the cast is not as recognisable as other war films I had previously watched such as Dunkirk and 1917, especially with those featuring some of my favourite actors such as Andrew Scott and Benedict Cumberbatch, who have become household names for people in the UK. All Quiet on the Western Front, however, blew these two films out of the water. The casting was phenomenal, especially Felix Kammerer, who played the protagonist. His emotional range throughout this film is an absolute whirlwind and is guaranteed to keep you hooked throughout the whole movie. 

One of my favourite scenes is when Kammerer's character Paul takes down a French soldier while retreating to the German trenches. Paul is seen watching him bleed out, but soon regrets what he has done and cannot bare to watch someone die because of him. He becomes hysterical and desperately tries to stop his bleeding to no avail. Upon his death, Paul finds a picture of a woman and a little girl in his pocket, who he soon realises to be the man's wife and child. He becomes inconsolable and lies beside the solider as he sobs with regret, realising that he has torn apart a family. This scene is incredibly powerful and highlights the fragility of life on the battlefield as well as the regrets that many faced by the men of the war. Kammerer's performance truly adds a heart-breaking feel to this scene that wouldn't be the same without him. 

It's also interesting to see Paul's overall character development throughout the film. As someone who never read the original novel, I didn't know what to expect when this film was originally suggested to me. Paul starts as an enthusiastic and honest young teen, who is ready to do anything for his country, but he is left broken by war and completely unrecognisable by the end. This also adds to the tear-jerking ending of this film, which I will not spoil. 

However, one major part of this film is its shock-factor. The gore and the grittiness of this film is something that cannot be ignored and was truly unexpected in my opinion. In films like Dunkirk and 1917, the gore is not a notable part of their narratives, it mainly focuses on their storyline. However, All Quiet on the Western Front plays mostly off its gore, with some truly horrifying images with are honestly haunting. For example, there is a particular scene that spring to mind where the Germans are under attack from allied forces, who are using tanks. The allies not only unload major artillery on the Germans but also run straight over their trenches. As disgusting as it sounds, you physically see the mangling of people under the tires of tanks, and it is truly horrifying to watch. So much so that when I suggested my friend watch this film, she called me in utter shock at what she had just seen. I would truly say this film is not for people with weak stomachs, but it only adds to the truth of this horrifying war. I do promise that this film is not all gory, some light-hearted scenes fill you with hope, such as the boys robbing a farm or their flirting with passing French female civilians. This film truly encompasses all elements of war. 

Overall, this movie is an absolute masterpiece and is undoubtedly one of the grittiest, yet most accurate war films I have ever seen. I adored this film and honestly see no way it could have improved.

A gritty film depicting the German side of the Great War. Dreams of heroism and praise from fighting in the war are immediately shattered as Paul (the main protagonist) finds himself and his friends facing the brutalities of war. 

Perhaps what I liked the most about this movie was the depiction of World War 1 from the German perspective, a view we don't often see in media (usually being seen through the lenses of the allies). The film also doesn't shy away from the realities of war. People are killed at any point for seemingly the most random and unfathomable of reasons other than that they were in the wrong place at the wrong time. Soldiers starve and steal from local communities just to survive, all while the suits back home eat entire feasts and sleep in warm beds. 

Truly a great remake of the original "All Quiet on the Western Front" and a great adaptation of the original novel of the same name.

All Quiet on the Western Front is one of the truly great anti-war novels, reading it is a harrowing experience. It's also essentially cinematically unadaptable in its original form, because it relies so heavily on introspection and internal monologues. With that in mind, this Edward Berger iteration is about as genuine as you can expect to be made in the medium, reiterating the antiwar message and translating the brutality to the muddy depths of the trenches. There are a few weaknesses, particularly veering away from the immersion of Felix Kammerer's Paul Bäumer to provide context in the negotiating table (it seems like the film wanted to take some cues from Paths of Glory) and staying clear of some of the novel's exceptionally bleak gallows humor. There is a whole host of supporting characters (the high command) that feel almost unnecessary to the story, just given how little insight they provide beyond being generically callous. 

Without the benefit of Paul's jaded and detached observations on the circumstances that led him into an industrialized hell and led millions of soldiers to their exceptionally unpleasant and near-pointless deaths on the back of vague ideals, All Quiet on the Western Front is a straightforward but visually striking antiwar film. It doesn't stick with you in the same way that the novel does, but it's about as well-executed as the text of the novel can be expected to be, with solid production value and performances alike. (3.5/5)

Hier wurde mit sehr hohem Aufwand ein eher fragwürdiges Werk abgeliefert. Die Handlung des Romans ist nur ansatzweise wiederzuerkennen. Die Macher wollten ihr eigenes Kunstwerk schaffen und ließen dabei das eigentliche Kunstwerk – also den Roman – über die Klinge springen. Den Film macht vor allem das Bemühen um das Kriegsgrauen aus. Gut gemeint. Aber das ist bekanntlich das Gegenteil von Kunst. 
Aber im Detail: 
Handlung:
Die Macher fühlten sich vollkommen frei, ihre eigene Geschichte zu erzählen. Die Vorgeschichte um den „Schleifer" Himmelstoß fällt vollkommen weg. Der Heimatbesuch Paul Bäumers, der die Entfremdung zeigt, fehlt ebenfalls. Die Figuren verlieren dadurch Identität und wirken den ganzen Film über wie Statisten, zu denen man keine Beziehung aufbaut. Deren Schicksal nimmt der Zuschauer dadurch erstaunlich gelassen zur Kenntnis. Die Kriegsbegeisterung am Anfang wird nur kurz über eine Gebrüllszene der Protagonisten gezeigt. Insgesamt ist die Handlung des Romans in dem Film nur schwer wiederzuerkennen. Allzu oft greifen die Macher in die Klischeekiste wie zum Beispiel beim fanatischen General, der Menschen trotz Aussichtslosigkeit in den Tod treibt. Die Handlung wurde dem „künstlerischen" Anspruch der Macher und der Botschaft, so wie sie sie verstanden haben wollten, gnadenlos untergeordnet. Dabei wäre weniger oft mehr gewesen. Der Tod von Paul Bäumer wirkt in der auf die Spitze getriebenen Sinnlosigkeitsdarstellung nicht tragisch sondern eher albern. Als Kat getötet wird, fragt man sich eigentlich nur, welche Botschaft denn nun hier wieder vermittelt werden sollte, dass es nötig war, die Handlung auf diese Weise umzugestalten. Die Macher haben nicht verstanden, dass die Tragik der Romanfiguren auch in der Art liegt, wie diese letztlich zu Tode gekommen sind. Ein verirrter Querschläger aus einem Kampfflugzeug und der Schuss eines Scharfschützen verbunden mit der totalen Resignation und fast dem Einverständnis zu genau dieses Schicksal, macht den Tod im Roman so tragisch. Er wurde zerstört, bevor er getötet wurde. Im Film findet man nichts davon. Hier deutet man den Tod um und lässt ihn durch einen fanatischen General in der letzten Minute des Kriegs den Tod laufen nachdem man ihn im feindlichen Schützengraben noch fleißig herumeifern sehen durfte. Albern. 
Schauspieler:
Hier ist das Elend der deutschen Schauspielerei deutlich zu sehen. Sitzen diese zusammen, werden Gesten und Gesichtsausdrücke durch den aktuellen Satz bestimmt, den sie aufsagen müssen, nicht durch den Charakter der Figuren, die sie spielen. Das Spielen wird dadurch zu einem Kaleidoskop der Grimassen, die den verschiedenen Sätzen folgen wie ein Hund dem Herrchen. Es wird brüllendes Lachen gespielt, weil irgendwo in der Regieanweisung steht, man sei ausgelassen bis heiter. Der Zuseher fragt sich, ob er grad eine Pointe verpasst hat oder warum die nun alle derartig Lachen wegen eines Satzes, den irgendjemand fallen lässt, aber der keinerlei Anlass für einen solchen Heiterkeitsausbruch gibt. Und wenn einer dann einen Satz später von etwas düsterem erzählt wird, düstert sich synchron dazu die Mimik ein. Es entsteht der Eindruck, dass die Schauspieler vor allem ihr schauspielerisches Genie zur Schau stellen möchten, statt der Figur, die sie spielen, eine Seele einzuhauchen. So kommt es auch, dass man die Szene, in der P.Bäumer seinen toten Freund im Schützengraben findet und ihn die Kleidung richtet, kaum emotional berührt. 
Dramaturgie:
Kurz: Ambitioniert, aber nicht gelungen. Wie schon gesagt, gibt es kaum Szenen, die einen emotional berühren. Patzer, wie die skurrilen Panzer auf rel. modernem Fahrwerk, die nicht entfernt Ähnlichkeit mit den englischen „Tanks" dieser Zeit haben, ist eines – das würde vielleicht den Aufwand sprengen? (kaum verständlich, wenn man die Möglichkeiten der Computer-VFX berücksichtigt). Dass diese aber agieren wie aus einem Film aus dem 2. WK verzeiht man schon weniger. Der Angriff im Verbund mit Infanterieunterstützung ist ein Konzept, das nicht in den 1. WK passt. Dort blieb die Panzerwaffe erstaunlich wirkungslos, eben WEIL man sie noch nicht in der o.a. Art und Weise einzusetzen wusste. 
Die Darstellung der Infanterieangriffe wirken im Film nicht besonders gelungen. Die strategische Tragödie des Grabenkriegs im WK I war das ständige Anstürmen im Rudel gegen ein Maschinengewehr nach Artillerievorbereitung. Im Film verzichtet man auf die Darstellung dieser dümmsten und sinnlosesten Art, einen Infanterieangriff zu führen. Man verzichtet auf die Darstellung des Grauens im Schützengraben, bevor der Pfiff aus der Signalpfeife einen in den sicheren Tod treibt. Man sieht Angriffe, kann aber den Ablauf nicht nachvollziehen, der diese Art der Kriegsführung so besonders menschenverachtend macht. Eine verpasste Chance, gerade wo der Schwerpunkt des Films auf Kriegsgräuel liegt. Man hat den Eindruck, die Macher haben gar nicht verstanden, wovon sie eigentlich berichten. Für sie besteht das Grauen des Kriegs vor allem in den dreckigen Gesichtern. Er ist dreckig, ergo leidet er. 
Da oder dort findet aber ein gelungenes Kontrastspiel zwischen Dreck/Kalt/Blut/Tod (Schützengräben) und Wärme/Ordnung/Wohlstand (Generalsquartier oder Verhandlungskom.) statt. Das ist aber das einzig da oder dort gelungene Dramaturgieelement. 
Fazit:
Wenn man sich derartig respektlos mit einem soliden Nichtwissen über den Roman oder die Verhältnisse im WK I an dieses Thema so heranmacht, wie die Macher dieses Films, verdient man keine Anerkennung. Vielleicht kürzt man das Fazit zu 3 Bereichen zusammen: 
Thema verfehlt, Thema nicht verstanden, das was man am Thema glaubt verstanden zu haben wurde schlecht umgesetzt. 
Aufwändig produziert und mit unnötigen Längen, trotz dieses Stoffs.

The big problem that I had with this film is co-writer and director Edward Berger's overzealous constant display of useless, and dragged out shots. The entire film is stuffed with style over substance, with many useless scenes that needed to end up on the cutting room floor. It's like this film wasn't even edited/cut down. An example is the French leader asking if the croissant was made today; who cares. It's ok to throw in the odd metaphor here and there, but there were far too many, in addition to the constant shots of an empty forest, the sky, etc, that added nothing to the film except annoyance. Sure there were undeniably powerful moments, but they were overshadowed by all over-stylization and lesser involving narrative that we've all seen in more inspiring war films. All three writers seemed to enjoy long sequences where very little of interest happens, and the little interest there is, is milked to the maximum time.

If this was cut down to about a 90 min runtime, the tension and suspense would be more appreciated and the narrative more engaging. And that's a shame, because this was so beautifully and realistically shot, with outstanding casting and performances, but had the writing and directing been better, this film would've been great, instead of just good. The score was very fitting - with the exception of the random outbursts of ear-pounding loud sound effects. Erich Maria Remarque's story of the First World War as told from the perspective of a German infantryman, has always been a defining, if not the defining description, of the horror and futility of war as told by it's vainglorious losers. Felix Kammerer as Paul is perfect as the otherwise sensitive protagonist who is taken apart piece by piece by the war and  Kat (Stanislaus) is excellent as his guide and friend. It also seems like a good time to tell this story again, with the war in Ukraine and the rise of nationalistic fervour, particularly for young people who may not know these stories like previous generations. It's the young that take centre stage in this film. It's their future the film is intensely preoccupied with, their hopes and dreams. It's a very stark warning to them that war is worse than anything you can imagine and, whatever you do, don't listen to the voices that would tell you otherwise.

We need to look at the movie from various perspectives first.
1. As an adaptation of famous and important novel. Well on this front it slightly failed from my point of view. We are following the same characters in the same place and time but the dynamics is bit different. 
2. We can dismiss the book and look at it purely as an war movie. From this perspective I must admit it's absolutely brilliant and might be one of the best WW1 depictions in movie format. I am not that big of an expert on WW1 but I think the movie depicted the conflict accurately and sensitively. The pacing of the story is great and you will get overall feel of the horrors, despair and pointlessness of the conflict.
3. We can also dismiss the historical accuracy of the movie and look at it just purely from technical/cinematographical point of view. From this perspective I also have to give the movie very high marks. The movie is "beautiful", camera and production design are top notch. Acting is great, sound effects and visual effects very well done. Music is quite forgettable but I dig it, you are not expecting "big hits" to take away from the very gritty story so that is actually working well with the rest. Story is presented in very captivating way and here I have to say that I think that the changes they made to it from the original book are actually working well for the movie experience. I have no problem if producers don't follow the book word by word in order to deliver overall feel and in this case it worked extremely well. I had the same feel from it as I remember from the book despite the changes. And that is something I appreciate a lot.
Overall, I can strongly recommend this movie.

This new version of "All Quiet on the Western Front" (Im Westen nichts Neues)  is the first German production of Erich Maria Remarque's classic anti-war novel as a film (The other two, the 1930 Oscar-winning classic and a Hallmark Hall of Fame version were American-made). This version doesn't dial back the brutality in any way, though I think the 1930 original is MUCH more brutal and graphic (even in black and white), and this color version is rated R for a reason. It's not quite as graphic as "Saving Private Ryan" in my opinion, but it is still pretty damn harsh and sometimes hard to watch, as it should be.
This new version (which I encourage you to watch in the original German with subtitles, though there is an English version) struck me as different right off the bat. It starts later in the war, 11 days from the Armistice instead of near the beginning of hostilities. It otherwise follows the established story of the novel pretty closely, though it actually includes a parallel story that counts down over that last week showing how Germany sued for an Armistice because of the horrible loss of life, and the French and Allies pretty much refused to grant it until they could dictate horrible terms that crushed the Germans and lit the flames that caused World War II 20 years later. The movie's ending is notably changed a bit (but still the same outcome) from the novel and the prior films, but that makes it even more painful to watch. It is, after all, an anti-war film and story from 1929 that hits the viewer hard and can be depressing, as in all the prior productions. 
I recommend it because it presents a tragic message that never changes; no matter how horrible the results of war are, no matter how much pain and tragedy is wrought upon civilians and soldiers alike, no matter how much needless death choreographed by fervent military leaders and government there is, nobody ever learns the lesson and history is condemned to repeat itself.

All Quiet on the Western Front is not anything like your standard Netflix movie. This is the closest I have ever felt to have a "movie going like" experience at home. The truth is this movie is one of the most intense, visceral, and brutal war movies I have ever seen in my life. For two and a half hours my eyes were fixed on the screen looking at the horror that was the western front during world war 1. There is no real story, rather just following a few select characters and experiencing the war. The production quality here is nothing short of brilliant. There is not one moment that I ever thought I was anywhere other than the trenches. The lighting, sound design, and cinematography are meticulous and all go towards immersion. The cast here is superb, actors do the most they can with very little screen time conveying the horror just before they pass. Felix Kammerer does a phenomenal job, you are right with him for the entire journey and his performance allows you to feel exactly what he feels in each moment. The action here is shot well, both lending to wide immersive shots of violence, then transitioning into close quarters combat within the trench itself. With all manner of artillery, machine gun fire, flamethrowers, and tanks.  However even with all the action, it never is glorified, never seems overstated. The director fundamentally understands that the true horror of war, there are no heroes. Men who once killed another man begging for his life soon find themselves at the opposite side of that equation. And more often than not ones survival can boil down to luck. This is a must see for anyone who enjoys war film, and one of the best in its genre.

Another remake of the classic tale which I'm sure you're already familiar with: set during World War I, 4 German friends enlist for military service to gain notoriety and respect once they've helped conquer the French and return home. Being young, naive, and believing the propaganda they've been fed, the friends believe they'll march in Paris within a matter of weeks and swiftly return home to a king's welcome. However, they soon realize war isn't as glamours as they were lead to believe, nor will a quick victory be obtained. Dealing with the physical, emotional, and psychological effects of war, the friends soon just try to survive to make it home alive. This rendition is completely in French and German which I appreciated (in fact, I believe it's submitted from Germany for consideration in the Best Foreign Film at next year's Oscars). Beautiful cinematography and sets, the story wastes little time in putting our 4 young lads right in the thick of it. With a runtime approaching 2 hours and 30 minutes, it can drag at times. If you're a fan of this story or of war films in general, this'll satisfy your itch for more of the same.
